column4: - in my experience, reformatting the usb stick, making sure the boot flag is set to "on" when you reformat it, sometimes helps
- of course that'll destroy all data currently on the usb stick
where is the boot flag in usb , is it a file or ??
- no, run gparted. this is the method i use (which again destroys all data on the usb stick so back it up if there's anything on there you want to keep)
i just opened it with "Disk Utility" and it says partion flag is bootable
file type should be FAT , correct ??
- ok good, yes fat16
- like Fyodorovna said, or try running Ubuntu's usb creator again - some computers simply won't boot from usb
i am going to try again lets see this time
so first i need to exit from freenode
tried once again reformatting usb disk but it does not seems to be detected at the boot time
any thing else you would like to suggest ???
any other disk creator ??
dude any more suggestion ??
dude tried with nusbbootin still the same, usb is not recognized at boot
any more suggestions
- do you have a usb key that you _can_ boot from? one that has another distro on it?
no, but will get from my friend and try again
you think the usb stick is not good ??
- as an obsessive type myself i would crank up gparted, create a new partition table, create a new partition, format with fat16, make sure the boot flag was set, and try again :-)
- but then that might not even work, no guarantees - it depends on how much time you want to spend dinking with it
